review.title: Constrained Sampling and Counting: Universal Hashing Meets SAT Solving
review.abstract: Constrained sampling and counting are two fundamental problems in artificial intelligence with a diverse range of applications, spanning probabilistic reasoning and planning to constrained-random verification. While the theory of these problems was thoroughly investigated in the 1980s, prior work either did not scale to industrial size instances or gave up correctness guarantees to achieve scalability. Recently, we proposed a novel approach that combines universal hashing and SAT solving and scales to formulas with hundreds of thousands of variables without giving up correctness guarantees. This paper provides an overview of the key ingredients of the approach and discusses challenges that need to be overcome to handle larger real-world instances.
histories: Appears in proceedings of AAAI-16 Workshop on Beyond NP
review.COMMENTS: Appears in proceedings of AAAI-16 Workshop on Beyond NP

sections.heading: 5 Hashing-Based Sampling and Counting

sections.heading: 6 Towards Scalable Sampling and Counting Algorithms
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to go to another world, where they can go to another world, where they can go to another world, where they can go to another world.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: Limited sampling and counting problems have a wide range of applications in artificial intelligence, verification, machine learning, and the like. Unlike previous work, which failed to provide scalable algorithms with strong theoretical guarantees, hashing-based techniques offer scalable sampling and counting algorithms with strong guarantees of the quality of the approach. However, many challenges remain to make this approach more practical for real-world problem cases. Promising directions for future research include the design of efficient hash functions and the development of SAT / SMT solvers specializing in overcoming constraints arising from these techniques.
